title: 113_s1085
content: The "Small Business Tax Certainty and Growth Act of 2013" aims to promote economic growth through comprehensive tax reform, including making the system fairer and simpler. It also proposes a permanent doubling of deductions for start-up expenses, organizational expenses, and syndication fees. The "Small Business Tax Certainty and Growth Act of 2013" proposes doubling deductions for start-up expenses, organizational expenses, and syndication fees in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments include increasing the limits from $5,000 to $10,000 and from $50,000 to $60,000. The "Small Business Tax Certainty and Growth Act of 2013" proposes doubling deductions for start-up expenses, organizational expenses, and syndication fees in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments include increasing the limits to $10,000 and $60,000 respectively. Effective Date: The amendments apply to amounts paid or incurred in taxable years ending on or after the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF CASH ACCOUNTING RULES FOR SMALL BUSINESS. The amendment allows certain small business taxpayers to use cash accounting method without limitation, as long as they meet specific criteria regarding gross receipts and are not subject to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment expands the gross receipts test for small business taxpayers from $5,000,000 to $10,000,000, allowing them to use the cash accounting method without limitation if they meet certain criteria and are not subject to specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2014 increases dollar amounts based on cost-of-living adjustments. Inventory rules clarified for small businesses under Section 471 of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to exempt small business taxpayers from using inventories for taxable years after December 31, 2013. Qualified taxpayers are not required to use inventories and their property will be treated as a material or supply. The term 'qualified taxpayer' includes eligible taxpayers defined in section 446(g)(2) and taxpayers described in section 448(b)(3). Section 474(c) is amended to adjust the dollar amount for the simplified dollar-value LIFO method. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2013, and any taxpayer changing their accounting method must initiate the change. The taxpayer must initiate any accounting method change, which is deemed consented by the Secretary of the Treasury. Adjustments required under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code must be spread over a period not exceeding 4 taxable years. SEC. 5. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF EXPENSING LIMITATION. The expensing limitation under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to set the dollar limitation at $250,000 and the reduction limitation at $800,000. Additionally, there will be an inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2014 to increase these amounts based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The expensing limitation under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to set the dollar limitation at $250,000 and the reduction limitation at $800,000. There will be an inflation adjustment for taxable years after 2014 based on the cost-of-living adjustment. The adjustment involves rounding to the nearest multiple of $1,000 for the dollar limitation and $10,000 for the phaseout amount. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to set the expensing limitation at $250,000 and the reduction limitation at $800,000. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including rounding amounts to the nearest multiple of $10,000. Effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2013. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF BONUS DEPRECIATION. Extension of bonus depreciation is amended for various dates in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Extension of bonus depreciation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended for different dates, including changes to dates like January 1, 2015 and January 1, 2014. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to change various dates, including substituting 'January 1, 2014' with 'January 1, 2015' in multiple clauses. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2013, in taxable years ending after that date. SEC. 7 extends the 15-year straight-line cost recovery for qualified leasehold improvements, qualified restaurant buildings, and improvements, and qualified retail improvements by amending certain clauses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2013.
